verses.verse: ((1 The Lord is Abram’s defense and reward.6 He is justified by faith.13 The servitude and deliverance out of Egypt is declared.18 The land of Canaan is promised the fourth time.) ) After these things, the (Or, the Lord spake to Abram.) word of the Lord came unto Abram in a (Cross references: : Num. 12:6) vision, saying, Fear not, Abram, I am thy buckler, and thine exceeding (Ps. 16:6) great reward.

And Abram said, (His fear was not only lest he should not have children, but lest the promise of the blessed seed should not be accomplished in him.) O Lord God, what wilt thou give me, seeing I go childless, and the steward of mine house is this Eliezer of Damascus?
Again Abram said, Behold, to me thou hast given no seed: wherefore lo, a servant of mine house shall be mine heir.
Then behold, the word of the Lord came unto him, saying, This man shall not be thine heir, but one that shall come out of thine own bowels, he shall be thine heir.
Moreover he brought him forth and said, (Rom. 4:18) Look up now unto heaven, and tell the stars if thou be able to number them: and he said unto him, So shall thy seed be.
And Abram (Rom. 4:3; Gal. 3:6; James 2:23) believed the Lord, and he counted that to him for righteousness.
Again he said unto him, I am the Lord, that brought thee out of (Gen. 11:28) Ur, of the Chaldeans, to give thee this land to inherit it.

And he said, O Lord God, (This is a particular motion of God’s Spirit, which is not lawful for all to follow, in asking signs: but was permitted to some by a peculiar motion, as to Gideon and Hezekiah.) Whereby shall I know that I shall inherit it?
Then he said unto him, Take me an heifer of three years old, and a she goat of three years old, and a ram of three years old, a turtle dove also and a pigeon.

So he took all these unto him, and (This was the old custom in making covenants, Jer. 34:18, to the which God added these conditions, that Abram’s posterity should be as torn in pieces, but after they should be coupled together: also that it should be assaulted, but yet delivered.) divided them in the midst, and laid every piece one against another: but the birds divided he not.
Then fowls fell on the carcasses, and Abram drove them away.
And when the sun went down, there fell an heavy sleep unto Abram: and lo, (Hebrew, a fear of great darkness.) a very fearful darkness fell upon him.

Then he said to Abram, (Acts 7:6) Know for a surety, that thy seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs, four hundred years, and shall serve them: and they entreat them evil. (Counting from the birth of Isaac to their departure out of Egypt: Which declareth that God will suffer his to be afflicted in this world.) (Exod. 12:40)
Notwithstanding, the nation whom they shall serve, will I judge: and afterward shall they come out with great substance.
But thou shalt go unto thy fathers in peace, and shalt be buried in a good age.

And in the (Or, after four hundred years.) fourth generation they shall come hither again: for the (Though God suffer the wicked for a time, yet his vengeance falleth upon them, when the measure of their wickedness is full.) wickedness of the Amorites is not yet full.
Also when the sun went down, there was a darkness: and behold, a smoking furnace, and a firebrand, which went between those pieces.

(Gen. 12:7; Gen. 13:15; Gen. 26:4; Deut. 4:5) In that same day the Lord made a covenant with Abram, saying, Unto thy seed have I given this land: (1 Kings 4:21; 2 Chron. 9:26) from the river of Egypt unto the great river (Hebrew, Perath.) Euphrates.
Then Kenites, and the Kenezzites, and the Kadmonites,
And the Hittites, and the Perizzites, and the Rephaims,
The Amorites also, and the Canaanites, and the Girgashites, and the Jebusites.
